title: FirstFT: JPMorgan chief warns US recession is ‘likely'
text:
JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon predicted the American economy will tip into a recession next year, warning the downturn threatened to spark “panic” in credit markets and wipe an additional 20 per cent from the value of US stocks.

The comments from Dimon, whose economic pronouncements are closely followed by investors, followed similar remarks last month by billionaire investor Ken Griffin and point to a growing consensus among senior figures on Wall Street about the likelihood of a US recession.

In an interview with CNBC on Monday, Dimon listed rising interest rates and Russia's invasion of Ukraine as factors stoking the risk of a downturn in 2023.

“These are very, very serious things, which I think are likely to push the US and the world — I mean, Europe is already in recession — and they're likely to put the US in some kind of recession six to nine months from now,” Dimon said.

Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Now, here is the rest of today's news — Abby

Five more stories in the news

1. Biden has few good options in responding to Opec cuts, analysts warn The US has promised to respond to the Opec+ decision to slash oil production but there are few meaningful options available, analysts have warned. Biden is trying to transition America away from fossil fuels and wants to keep domestic petrol prices down, but must also consider the impact on Europe of any action.

2. Ex-Fed chair wins Nobel economics prize Ben Bernanke, the former US Federal Reserve chair, has been awarded this year's prize in economics alongside Douglas Diamond of the University of Chicago and Philip Dybvig of Washington University in St Louis for their work on the role of banks in the economy and financial crises.

3. Fed's dash for higher rates risks world recession, EU diplomat warns Central banks are being forced to follow the Fed's multiple rate rises to prevent their currencies from slumping against the dollar, EU top diplomat Josep Borrell said, warning that the Fed's actions risk tipping the world into a recession.

4. Corporate giants resist making political spending disclosures Berkshire Hathaway, Tesla and CME Group are among more than two dozen S&P 500 companies that disclose no information about their political spending, according to an annual transparency report from the Center for Political Accountability published ahead of US midterm elections.

5. Rivian shares slump after recall of electric trucks Shares in Amazon-backed electric truckmaker Rivian tumbled more than 7 per cent to a three-month low on Monday after it announced a recall of around 12,200 vehicles because of a loose nut, according to a filing Rivian made with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

The day ahead

IMF meetings The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will commence their second day of meetings in Washington today. The fund will release its World Economic Outlook report in which it is expected to have downgraded its global economic forecasts. The IMF will also release its Global Financial Stability report.

Fedspeak Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland president Loretta Mester will deliver a speech on monetary policy and the economic outlook at the Signature Luncheon hosted by the Economic Club of New York. Philadelphia Fed president Patrick Harker will discuss the impact so-called anchor institutions, like higher education and hospitals, have on regional economies at the Young Smart & Local conference in Greensboro, North Carolina.

Inflation expectations The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will release its survey of consumer expectations and will provide insight on Americans' views on inflation and its outlook.

Nikola trial A jury is expected to hear closing arguments today for the fraud trial of Trevor Milton, founder of electric vehicle company Nikola, who is accused of misleading investors. Milton has pleaded not guilty to two counts of securities fraud and two counts of wire fraud.

Brazil consumer prices Inflation in Brazil is expected to have moderated in September, with economists polled by Refinitiv predicting consumer prices to have cooled to an annualised pace of 7.1 per cent, down from 8.73 per cent in August. Moderating inflation could be good news for Brazil's incumbent president Jair Bolsonaro as he faces former president Luiz Inacio Lula Da Silva in a run-off election at the end of the month.

What else we're reading

Russian strikes expose Ukraine's air defence shortage Russia's attacks on Ukraine's biggest cities will force Kyiv to choose between deploying its scarce air defence systems to protect civilians or using them to press ahead with the counteroffensives that have reclaimed huge swaths of territory. Ukraine's defence ministry said more than half of the projectiles fired during morning rush hour were shot down, but dozens still struck Kyiv and other population centres, killing civilians and damaging civil infrastructure.

Why Elon Musk didn't exit his Twitter bid Before indicating last week that he wanted to go ahead with the buyout of Twitter, the Tesla chief was apparently wavering. A US court ruling over generic drugmaker Akorn serves as a lesson of how hard it would be for any corporate acquirer to walk away, writes Sujeet Indap.

US property sector braces for job cuts as interest rates crush home sales Realtors, mortgage brokers, and appraisers across the US are bracing for widespread job cuts as home sales plummet amid rising interest rates. “It went from feast to famine, from everybody buying to turtle slow,” said Linda McCoy, board president of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers.

Sterling slump frustrates expansion of ‘magic circle' law firms Britain's largest international law firms are struggling to attract and retain staff in the US after the crash in the value of sterling compounded fears that foreign exchange fluctuations would erode salaries.

Ben & Jerry's vs Unilever The ice cream maker's decision to end its franchise deal in Israel to prevent its product from being sold in occupied Palestinian territories has placed it at odds with its parent company, turning a star acquisition into a legal nightmare for Unilever.

Fashion

Why are we still obsessed with green?  “The fashion industry didn't invent our desire for green, it just read the room. It is surely not a coincidence that green is the decreed colour of environmentalism, something the fashion industry has an awkward relationship with,” writes Kate Finnigan.
